Lensed events

Notes:

  • for source properties and its distribution, refer to unlensed section

  • LeR loosely follow lensed rate calculation from WIERDA et al. 2021

Parameters in consideration: \(\text{SL}\): Strong lensing, \(z_L\): redshift of galaxy lens, \(R_o^L\): merger rate distribution (optical depth applied), \(\mathcal{O}\): detectability condition, \(\theta_L\): lens parameters, \(\beta\): source position, \(\mu_i\): magnifications, \(\Delta t_i\): time delays.

Detectable lensed events’ rate in a year

  • Detectable lensed events’ rate in a year is given by

\begin{equation} \begin{split} R_L = \mathcal{N}^L \int & dz_s R_o^L(z_s) \,\mathcal{O}_{images}(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i, \rho_{th}) \, \\ & \, P(\theta) P(\theta_L, z_L|\text{SL},z_s) P(\beta|\text{SL}) d\theta d\beta dz_L d\theta_L dz_s \end{split} \tag{1} \end{equation}

  • \(\mathcal{O}_{images}(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i, \rho_{th})\) is the detectability condition for lensed events

  • \(P(\theta)\), \(P(\theta_L, z_L|\text{SL},z_s)\), \(P(\beta|\text{SL})\) are the distributions of GW parameters, lens parameters, and source position for lensed events, respectively.

  • They are considered normalized.

  • \(R_o^L(z_s)\) is the normalized merger-rate distribution for strong lensing case \begin{equation}

  • \(\mathcal{N}^L\) is the normalization factor for strong lensing case.

SNR operator

  • For 2 image detectable (i.e. 2 super threshold events).

  • SNR operator over all images follows,

\[\begin{split}\mathcal{O}_{images}(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i, \rho_{th}) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ c l } 1 & \sum_i^{images} \Theta[\rho(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i)-\rho_{th}]\ge 2 \\ 0 & \text{otherwise} \end{array} \right.\end{split}\]

\begin{equation} \tag{2} \end{equation}

  • \(\Theta\) is the Heaviside step function.

  • \(\rho(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i)\) is the SNR of the \(i_{\text{th}}\) image.

Lensed BBH/BNS merger rate distribution wrt \(z_s\).

  • The merger rate distribution for lensed events (source frame) is given by,

\begin{equation} R(z_s) = \frac{\mathcal{R}_m(z_s)}{1+z_s} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} \tau(z_s) \tag{3} \end{equation}

  • \(\tau(z_s)\) is the optical depth for strong lensing.

  • \(\mathcal{N}^L\) is the normalizing factor of merger rate distribution (with strong lensing condition applied) wrt \(z_s\).

\begin{equation} \mathcal{N}^L = \int_{z_{min}}^{z_{max}} dz_s \frac{R_m(z_s)}{1+z_s} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} \tau(z_s) \tag{4} \end{equation}

  • Normalized merger rate distribution for lensed events wrt \(z_s\) is given by,

\begin{equation} R_o^L(z_s)= \frac{1}{\mathcal{N}^L}\frac{R_m(z_s)}{1+z_s} \frac{dV_c}{dz_s} \tau(z_s) \tag{5} \end{equation}

  • Sampling of \(z_s\) is done through rejection sampling with the merger rate formula given above (lensing condition applied).

  • Source param: \(\theta \in \{m_1,m_2,D_l,\iota,\phi,\psi,ra,dec\}\)

  • Lens param: \(\theta_L \in \{\sigma \text{(velocity-dispersion)},\; q \text{(axis-ratio)},\; \psi \text{(axis-rotaion)},\; \gamma \text{(spectral-index)},\)\(\; [\gamma_1,\gamma_2] \text{(external-shear)} \}\)

  • \(z_L\) : redshift of the galaxy lens

  • image param: \(\{\beta \text{(source position)},\; \mu \text{(magnification)},\; dt \text{(time-delay)}\}\)

Sampling methods for lens parameters

Parameter

\(\gamma_1,\gamma_2\)

None

Normal dist.

[mu,sigma]=[0,0.05]

\(\psi\)

\(\gamma\)

None

Normal dist.

[mu,sigma]=[2,0.2]

\(z_L\) from \(D_L^c=r D_s^c\)

None

[\(z_{min}\),\(z_{max}\)]

\(r\)as in\(D_L^c=r D_s^c\)

None

\(P(x)=30x^2(1-x)^2\)

\(b<0.8\)

Image parameters

  • Einstein radius: \begin{equation} \theta_E = \frac{4\pi \sigma^2}{c^2}\frac{D_{Ls}}{D_s} \tag{7} \end{equation}

  • Souce position in lens plane : \(\beta = [x,y] = [\eta\,cos(\phi),\eta\,sin(\phi)]\)

  • sampling methods:

    Parameter

    unit

    sampling method

    \(\eta\)

    \(\theta_E\)

    within caustic

    \(\phi\)

    radian

    within caustic

Montecarlo integration

  • With step function.

\begin{equation} \begin{split} R_L &= \mathcal{N}^U \left< \mathcal{O}_{images}(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i, \rho_{th})\,\right>_{z_s,z_L,\theta,\theta_L \in \text{Sampled}[z_s,z_L,\theta,\theta_L]} \\ &= \frac{\mathcal{N}^U}{N} \sum_i \mathcal{O}_{images}(z_s,\theta,\mu_i,\Delta t_i, \rho_{th}) \end{split} \tag{8} \end{equation}

  • With Pdet.

\begin{equation} \begin{split} R_L &= \mathcal{N}^U \left< \,P_{det}^{max(\rho)_1} \,P_{det}^{max(\rho)_2} \,\right>_{z_s,z_L,\theta,\theta_L \in \text{Sampled}[z_s,z_L,\theta,\theta_L]} \\ &= \frac{\mathcal{N}^U}{N} \sum_i \,P_{det}^{max(\rho)_1} \,P_{det}^{max(\rho)_2} \end{split} \tag{9} \end{equation}

  • \(max(\rho)_1\) : \(1^{st}\) maximum SNR out of all the images for the given parameters {\(z_s,z_L,\theta,\theta_L\)}.

  • \(max(\rho)_2\) : \(2^{st}\) maximum SNR out of all the images for the given parameters {\(z_s,z_L,\theta,\theta_L\)}.

  • \(\rho_{th}\) for \(max(\rho)_2\) can lower than that of \(max(\rho)_1\) if it is a subthreshhold search.
